39.text: As you're all aware, we face difficult economic times.

43.text: I come to you with a modest proposal

48.text: This idea came to me while talking to

50.text: a physicist friend of mine at MIT.

53.text: He was struggling to explain something to me:

56.text: a beautiful experiment that uses lasers to cool down matter.

60.text: Now he confused me from the very start,

62.text: because light doesn't cool things down.

64.text: It makes it hotter. It's happening right now.

68.text: The reason that you can see me standing here is because

70.text: this room is filled with more than 100 quintillion photons,

74.text: and they're moving randomly through the space, near the speed of light.

78.text: All of them are different colors,

81.text: and they're bouncing off every surface, including me,

84.text: and some of those are flying directly into your eyes,

86.text: and that's why your brain is forming an image of me standing here.

91.text: It also uses photons, but they're all synchronized,

95.text: and if you focus them into a beam,

98.text: what you have is an incredibly useful tool.

100.text: The control of a laser is so precise

103.text: that you can perform surgery inside of an eye,

105.text: you can use it to store massive amounts of data,

108.text: and you can use it for this beautiful experiment

110.text: that my friend was struggling to explain.

113.text: First you trap atoms in a special bottle.

116.text: It uses electromagnetic fields to isolate the atoms

119.text: from the noise of the environment.

121.text: And the atoms themselves are quite violent,

124.text: but if you fire lasers that are precisely tuned to the right frequency,

128.text: an atom will briefly absorb those photons

132.text: Little by little it gets colder

135.text: until eventually it approaches absolute zero.

140.text: Now if you use the right kind of atoms and you get them cold enough,

147.text: It's no longer a solid, a liquid or a gas.

150.text: It enters a new state of matter called a superfluid.

154.text: The atoms lose their individual identity,

156.text: and the rules from the quantum world take over,

159.text: and that's what gives superfluids such spooky properties.

163.text: For example, if you shine light through a superfluid,

166.text: it is able to slow photons down

179.text: Another spooky property is that it flows

182.text: with absolutely no viscosity or friction,

185.text: so if you were to take the lid off that bottle,

189.text: A thin film will creep up the inside wall,

192.text: flow over the top and right out the outside.

196.text: Now of course, the moment that it does hit the outside environment,

199.text: and its temperature rises by even a fraction of a degree,

203.text: it immediately turns back into normal matter.

205.text: Superfluids are one of the most fragile things we've ever discovered.

208.text: And this is the great pleasure of science:

211.text: the defeat of our intuition through experimentation.

215.text: But the experiment is not the end of the story,

217.text: because you still have to transmit that knowledge to other people.

220.text: I have a Ph.D in molecular biology.

223.text: I still barely understand what most scientists are talking about.

226.text: So as my friend was trying to explain that experiment,

229.text: it seemed like the more he said,

235.text: Because if you're trying to give someone the big picture

237.text: of a complex idea, to really capture its essence,

242.text: the fewer words you use, the better.

245.text: In fact, the ideal may be to use no words at all.

248.text: I remember thinking, my friend could have explained

250.text: that entire experiment with a dance.

253.text: Of course, there never seem to be any dancers around when you need them.

257.text: Now, the idea is not as crazy as it sounds.

259.text: I started a contest four years ago called Dance Your Ph.D.

263.text: Instead of explaining their research with words,

265.text: scientists have to explain it with dance.

268.text: Now surprisingly, it seems to work.

271.text: Dance really can make science easier to understand.

274.text: But don't take my word for it.

276.text: Go on the Internet and search for "Dance Your Ph.D."

279.text: There are hundreds of dancing scientists waiting for you.

282.text: The most surprising thing that I've learned while running this contest

284.text: is that some scientists are now working directly with dancers on their research.

289.text: For example, at the University of Minnesota,

291.text: there's a biomedical engineer named David Odde,

294.text: and he works with dancers to study how cells move.

297.text: They do it by changing their shape.

299.text: When a chemical signal washes up on one side,

302.text: it triggers the cell to expand its shape on that side,

305.text: because the cell is constantly touching and tugging at the environment.

309.text: So that allows cells to ooze along in the right directions.

312.text: But what seems so slow and graceful from the outside

316.text: is really more like chaos inside,

319.text: because cells control their shape with a skeleton of rigid protein fibers,

323.text: and those fibers are constantly falling apart.

326.text: But just as quickly as they explode,

329.text: more proteins attach to the ends and grow them longer,

333.text: just to remain exactly the same.

336.text: Now, David builds mathematical models of this and then he tests those in the lab,

339.text: but before he does that, he works with dancers

342.text: to figure out what kinds of models to build in the first place.

349.text: and when I visited David to learn about his research,

351.text: he used dancers to explain it to me

355.text: rather than the usual method: PowerPoint.

359.text: And this brings me to my modest proposal.

361.text: I think that bad PowerPoint presentations

364.text: are a serious threat to the global economy.

375.text: Now it does depend on how you measure it, of course,

380.text: but one estimate has put the drain at 250 million dollars per day.

387.text: for an average audience of four people

393.text: about a quarter of the presentations are a complete waste of time,

397.text: and given that there are some apparently

400.text: 30 million PowerPoint presentations created every day,

403.text: that would indeed add up to an annual waste

409.text: Of course, that's just the time we're losing

413.text: There are other costs, because PowerPoint is a tool,

418.text: and like any tool, it can and will be abused.

421.text: To borrow a concept from my country's CIA,

424.text: it helps you to soften up your audience.

427.text: It distracts them with pretty pictures, irrelevant data.

431.text: It allows you to create the illusion of competence,

437.text: and most destructively, the illusion of understanding.

442.text: So now my country is 15 trillion dollars in debt.

446.text: Our leaders are working tirelessly to try and find ways to save money.

451.text: One idea is to drastically reduce public support for the arts.

456.text: For example, our National Endowment for the Arts,

461.text: slashing that program would immediately reduce the national debt

464.text: by about one one-thousandth of a percent.

467.text: One certainly can't argue with those numbers.

469.text: However, once we eliminate public funding for the arts,

477.text: The artists on the street will swell the ranks of the unemployed.

481.text: Many will turn to drug abuse and prostitution,

484.text: and that will inevitably lower property values in urban neighborhoods.

487.text: All of this could wipe out the savings we're hoping to make in the first place.

492.text: I shall now, therefore, humbly propose my own thoughts,

495.text: which I hope will not be liable to the least objection.

499.text: Once we eliminate public funding for the artists,

501.text: let's put them back to work

502.text: by using them instead of PowerPoint.

505.text: As a test case, I propose we start with American dancers.

509.text: After all, they are the most perishable of their kind,

511.text: prone to injury and very slow to heal

513.text: due to our health care system.

519.text: we should use dance to explain all of our complex problems.

525.text: to explain why we must invade a foreign country

529.text: or bail out an investment bank.

534.text: Of course someday, in the deep future,

540.text: even more powerful than PowerPoint may be invented,

544.text: rendering dancers unnecessary as tools of rhetoric.

547.text: However, I trust that by that day,

550.text: we shall have passed this present financial calamity.

553.text: Perhaps by then we will be able to afford the luxury

556.text: of just sitting in an audience

561.text: than to witness the human form in motion.
